note: The plural form 'מילים' (milim) is grammatically masculine, despite the singular 'מילה' (milah) being feminine.

example_sentences.note: 'הביתה' (habaytah) is a directional form meaning 'homeward' or 'to home'.

note: Spelled the same as the masculine singular present tense of the verb 'לאכול' (le'ekhol - to eat).

example_sentences.translation_english: There is a lot of food on the table.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك الكثير من الطعام على الطاولة.

example_sentences.translation_english: I am eating an apple now.

note: This noun is always grammatically plural (pluralia tantum), even when referring to a single body/instance of water.
This is an irregular verb. The infinitive form differs significantly from the present tense forms (e.g., הולך - holekh).

example_sentences.translation_english: He is walking in the street.

note: The masculine singular present tense form 'אוכל' (okhel) is spelled the same as the noun 'אוכל' (okhel - food).

example_sentences.translation_english: I want to talk to you.

note: Pronunciation varies: usually 've', changes to 'u' before letters ב, ו, מ, פ or a shva, and 'va' before certain vowel combinations.
Pronunciation varies: usually 'be', changes to 'ba' when attached to a word with the definite article (בּ + ה = בַּ).

example_sentences.translation_english: The book is on the table.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: There is a book on the table.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: There are three doors in the room.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: I am writing with a pen.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: I am working on the computer.
There are many computers in the office.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من أجهزة الحاسوب في المكتب.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: There are many cars on the road.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من السيارات على الطريق.

note: The plural form עָרִים ('arim) is irregular.

example_sentences.translation_english: I live in a big city.
There are many cities in Israel.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من المدن في إسرائيل.

example_sentences.translation_english: There are three rooms in the apartment.

note: Kesef is generally used in singular form in modern Hebrew for the concept of money.

example_sentences.translation_english: I need money to buy a book.
I need money to buy a book.

note: Zman is generally used in singular form for the concept of time.

example_sentences.translation_english: It takes a lot of time.
There are many people in the street.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك الكثير من الناس في الشارع.

example_sentences.translation_english: The boy is playing in the park.
The girl is reading a book.
There are many girls in the class.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من الفتيات في الصف.

example_sentences.translation_english: I work in a big company.
He is a good Hebrew teacher.
The teachers in the school teach well.
The students are studying for the test.
The doctor told me to rest.

example_sentences.translation_english: There are many good doctors in this city.

example_sentences.translation_english: I went to the bank to withdraw money.
